Clay Phillips.Action: Helps Sam Ellis hammer the rim on the wheel without complaint.
Gently takes the cigarette from his young brother Steve to help him seal it and smokes it.
Engages in light, friendly teasing with Sam and Steve, showing amiability and tolerance.
Helps the blacksmith by picking up a hammer and assisting in hammering the rim on the wheel, working steadily and practically.
Takes the cigarette from his younger brother Steve and successfully seals it, showing some skill and confidence.
Makes a wry, somewhat impatient comment about the slow pace of the work, indicating awareness and realistic assessment.
Offers to take care of Steve confidently, demonstrating leadership in a casual, good-natured way.
Suggests both he and Steve look at the situation, showing willingness to assess and participate actively.
Engages with others calmly and perceptively, as when he asks who the bodies are, indicating situational awareness.
Expresses shock and sympathy upon hearing about the Forster family murders.
Engages politely and respectfully with Sheriff Gardner and others, greeting them cordially.
Shows concern when confronted with facts, asking questions rather than dismissing the situation.
Responds calmly and thoughtfully upon hearing disturbing news; asks relevant questions to understand the situation.
Initially shows confusion and fails to immediately connect the burned jacket and the killings to himself or his ranch.
Discusses concern for a jailed man who killed someone, buys a rifle for him to avoid him crying.
Jokes lightly and grins while talking about serious matters.
Explains a strategic plan using beans and hardtack to map out enemy movements and anticipate Lednov's route.
Keeps information close to the vest initially, showing discretion and control over sensitive information.
Laughs with Steve after a tense conversation about an adversary.
Stops to pick up a woman's hat found on the road.
Stops to help with the spilled contents, starts tossing clothes back in the trunk.
Reassures Steve that he'll have clothes if things get tough next winter.
Takes a small folding daguerreotype case delicately ornamented, tucks it into his pocket.
Hurries up to check on the surrey accident and asks if anybody is hurt.
Notices the broken trunk and takes initiative to gather and organize spilled clothes carefully.
Carefully picks up and pockets the folding daguerrotype case, showing awareness and attention to detail.
Spurs his horse forward promptly when spotting the disabled surrey, showing responsiveness and situational awareness.
Drops reins and hurries to check on the condition of those at the broken wheel, implying quick assessment and prioritizing welfare.
Stops Helen with a look to prevent further complaining, then examines and lightly jokes about the broken wheel.
Introduces himself and his brother politely to Mary and Helen.
Listens and engages respectfully with Mary and Helen, answering their questions.
Begins to roll a cigarette without responding to the offer to ride together or the mention of payment, showing non-committal behavior.
Offers to help load the wagon and carry things toward it.
States women would be in the way on the tough trip, implying they can't join all the way.
Asks about Elaine’s condition with genuine concern.
Takes charge of the situation by organizing belongings into the wagon and offering to take the group to the first ranch, showing practical leadership.
Acknowledges his physical limitation (can't carry everyone) and sets realistic expectations for the journey, demonstrating prudent judgment.
Ignores Mary's sarcastic comment about women being 'in the way' and redirects focus to practical matters, showing confidence and ability to maintain control.
Asked whether he can fix the surrey, he turns from Elaine but no clear indication of whether he is able to or willing to fix it is shown, making this neutral.
Notices the folding daguerreotype case and produces it from his pocket to help Elaine.
Kicks the unbroken back wheel to break the awkward silence, showing situational awareness and calmness.
Introduces himself and his brother politely and confidently.
Gently lifts Elaine up to help her into the wagon, showing kindness and attentiveness.
Unrolls a bedroll under a shaded area and instructs Elaine to stretch out there, demonstrating practical thinking and care.
Informs Elaine and Mary about the ranch and reassures them calmly, providing useful information and reducing their anxiety.
Turns quickly and hurries back to the surrey after addressing their worries, indicating an efficient, task-focused approach.
Commands Steve to get his rifle upon sensing potential danger.
Kicks dirt over the campfire, likely to extinguish it for safety.
Shakes his head to signal caution to Steve instead of shooting an approaching horseman.
Kicks dirt over the fire upon sensing a nearby horseman, signaling an intention to extinguish the light to avoid detection.
Shakes his head to silently communicate with Steve a decision not to shoot, showing situational awareness and control.
Moves closer and extends his hand to Clayton, shaking hands and introducing himself and his brother warmly.
Cordially invites Clayton to get his horse and join them despite initial tension with rifles drawn.
Commands Clayton to drop his gun in a firm but not hostile manner.
Commands 'Hold it' decisively to stop a potentially dangerous situation.
Orders a suspicious man, Clayton, to drop his gun and keeps his rifle ready, showing tactical caution.
Responds to Clayton's mild challenge without escalating tension, then lowers rifle after assessing the situation.
Offers a cordial handshake and introduction, moving to establish trust and cooperation quickly.
Invites Clayton to join them and continue the search, coordinating efforts effectively.
Supports Jim's decision to marry Marcia despite family disapproval.
Dismisses Mary's concerns with a sarcastic remark about finding another girl.
Avoids engaging directly in a personal question, showing embarrassment but tries to deflect tension with a smile and suggesting Steve get wood.
Jumps into the conversation to defend Jim and Marcia's decision, showing confidence in their choice despite social objections.
Dismisses concerns of others without fully engaging or addressing them thoughtfully, showing some social tactlessness.
When pressed by Mary, he avoids the emotional complexity by saying he's not in Jim's shoes and removing himself from the argument, indicating a lack of handling difficult conversations skillfully.
Reacts to social awkwardness by quickly changing the subject to a mundane task, indicating discomfort but ability to defuse tension.
Knows and appreciates practical skills and survival knowledge that Steve has, recognizing his competence in areas beyond formal literacy.
Interrupts Steve somewhat abruptly to enforce bedtime, demonstrating a confident and decisive approach to guidance.
Avoids explaining fully why Steve is kept away from Mary, suggesting possible discomfort or unwillingness to confront social issues directly.
Immediately stops smoking and goes to investigate when Elaine is missing.
Tells Mary sharply to stay put and not wander off after Elaine.
Shows concern by instructing Mary to build the fire and stay close, and partners with Steve to search for Elaine.
Immediately reacts to Elaine's disappearance by taking charge, telling Mary to stay by the fire and preparing to search with Steve.
Questions the reason for Elaine running off, showing skepticism which may indicate thoughtful consideration.
Does not panic and gives clear, calm instructions during a stressful situation.
Organizes the group, directs Mary to build the fire and stay close, takes initiative by saddling his horse and riding out to search for Elaine.
Shows annoyance and is somewhat uncertain when trying to deduce Elaine's location from the camp, indicating some worry but limited information.
Reins his horse in and turns to look in the direction of a rifle shot, indicating alertness and situational awareness.
Sternly insists Steve return to the horses when they are straying.
Acknowledges Steve's learning to read but emphasizes responsibilities, showing practical concern.
Admits he intended to teach Steve to read but never found the time, showing some regret and sincere intention.
Rides out to retrieve a straying horse and helps Steve get horses back in line.
Shares past difficult experiences candidly with his brother Steve, showing openness and trust.
Advises Steve to prepare carefully by getting the new rifle, showing concern for his safety.
Reflects on not being 'much on killin'' despite having the opportunity, indicating a restraint and possibly a compassionate attitude.
Rides back through the rain toward the wagon when he hears Helen crying out.
Drops the reins, climbs into the wagon, and puts his hand on Elaine's forehead to check on her condition.
Fixes the tarp to give more protection to the sick girl despite the harsh weather.
Responds dryly to Mary's anxious tone but continues to care for Elaine.
Rides ahead to scout the trail, notices a light in the valley and evaluates the situation.
Informs the group about the distance remaining and checks on the wellbeing of Elaine.
Greets Wyatt warmly, shakes hands with Mrs. Wyatt, acknowledging their relief at his arrival.
Jokes dryly about the killers looking for him, showing some openness and sincerity.
Hints he's about to deliver bad news despite their happiness to see him, showing honesty but potentially dampening the mood.
Gallops into the yard, promptly dismounts, approaches the farmhouse decisively, and calmly reveals his identity to Wyatt, showing awareness of the situation and confidence in his interaction.

Makes a quick, informed deduction about the identity of the men riding through the gate based on their matched roans and mentions that they are looking for him, indicating situational awareness and intelligence.

Warns Mrs. Wyatt that she might not feel good about seeing him after he tells her what he stopped in for, implying he has important and possibly bad news, showing responsible communication and readiness to face consequences.
Picked up some women on the road, including one who is sick, and brought them to the Wyatt home.
Expressed hesitation and prejudice about the women not being the sort of people the Wyatts were used to.
Complies respectfully when asked to leave by Mrs. Wyatt without argument.
Sharp reminder to Mary about the girl's parents, highlighting concern and awareness.
Suggests staying longer to avoid a long walk back to Aspen, showing consideration for others' wellbeing.
Apologizes to Mr. Wyatt for unknowingly involving his daughter and expresses regret.
States he can't take Wyatt's daughter with him but does so in a sincere, regretful manner.
Challenges Wyatt by saying 'You're not bein' quite fair,' showing a willingness to engage and stand up in a difficult situation.
Apologizes sincerely to Mr. Wyatt, acknowledging his mistake about not knowing who she was.
Rolls and lights a cigarette calmly while having a tense conversation, showing composure.
States he cannot take her with him, showing decisiveness and clear boundaries.
Challenges Wyatt by saying 'You're not bein' quite fair.'
Fails to persuade Wyatt or change the situation despite attempts to argue fairness.
Enters the kitchen carrying girls' suitcases and blankets, quietly settles the girls in a room, offers coffee politely, and moves about calmly and thoughtfully.
Engages in conversation about a hopeful future and listens attentively to Mary's descriptions of 'the girl in gingham'.
Responds dryly to Mary's romanticized vision by joking he will make the soap himself.
Smiles faintly after Mary leaves, indicating a positive, warm regard despite being unsure of her intentions.
Is focused on working on the wagon, seemingly indifferent to pleas for help to speed the women's travel plans.
Notices something is wrong and steps into the bedroom to check on Elaine and Mrs. Wyatt.
Responds sharply to Elaine’s concerns to prevent them from taking her away.
Realizes something is wrong and steps into the bedroom to assess the situation.
Responds sharply and confidently tells Elaine that 'No they won't' in regard to people spoiling everything.
Initially says 'Well, I'm off --' before realizing the problem, showing a momentary lack of awareness.
Ignores Steve's plea to take in the girls, responds curtly and walks away without discussion.
Permits Mary to smile at Helen and allows her to continue with her learning and presence near the wagon.
Orders to round up the horses and load the wagon efficiently, focusing on task completion.
Rides ahead of the wagon with a rifle across his legs, acting as a lookout and escort.
Watches his brother and Mary with a serious expression, does not participate in their lighthearted interaction.
Cautiously scouts the trail, dismounts, and carefully observes the approaching horsemen before signaling his group to stop quietly.
Waves at his group to stop and be quiet, then moves swiftly to intercept the wagon, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Instructs Mary and Steve clearly to prepare for staying until dark and securing the horses with hobbles.
Surveys the surroundings from a hilltop at dusk, showing situational awareness.
Hesitates briefly after Mary questions him but then moves to saddle his mare, indicating some restraint and reflection.
Stops to let the wagon come abreast, dismounts to take reins, motions Mary to move over while showing concern for safety.
Expresses distrust of Mary driving on the dangerous trail but suggests she rest because she must be tired, showing care.
Hands reins to Mary and takes his rifle, showing trust and protecting the group.
Warily assesses the situation when confronted by Fowler, cautious but not hostile.
Hands reins to Mary, takes rifle, dismounts quickly, frees horse, and gallops ahead warily with rifle ready, showing alertness and skill in navigating dangerous terrain.
Stops and assesses situation upon hearing pebbles, cautiously looks up at muzzle of rifle, prepares to raise gun but listens to voice commanding 'Hold it!'
Remains wary and puzzled when confronted by an unknown man, showing caution but not overreacting.
Responds to Fowler's question calmly and straightforwardly, indicating confidence and composure.
Calmly redirects Steve's attention from his kiss with Mary to the work with the wagon, showing practical focus.
Explains complex emotional/social boundaries to Steve with patience despite being embarrassed.
Suddenly leaves Mary to join Steve without clear communication, potentially avoiding emotional confrontation.
Directs Steve clearly to take the grub box and help with breakfast, then efficiently moves the bed roll and shifts around the wagon.
Stares after Steve silently without further instructions or checks, showing calm confidence in delegated task.
Kisses Mary hard and ruthlessly, crushes her shoulders with his hands.
Is silent when Mary seeks a declaration of love, causing her hurt.
Responds to Mary’s request for words with hardness and dismisses her feelings.
Admits that he finds it difficult to say pretty speeches even when he means them.
Hesitates then follows Mary after she leaves, suggesting some care despite the tension.
Refuses to provide comforting or sincere emotional expressions when Mary seeks verbal affirmation, demonstrating emotional guardedness and lack of communicative openness.
Maintains control over the interaction without giving in to emotional pressure, showing confidence and self-possession in a difficult interpersonal situation.
Hesitates before following Mary to camp, indicating a moment of internal conflict or uncertainty.
Silently picks up his saddle bags and prepares to leave without disrupting the conversation.
Quietly enters, picks up saddle bags calmly, displays no hesitation or confusion in action.
Listens attentively as Mary discusses plans, remains composed, does not interrupt or show signs of misunderstanding.
Does not engage or argue despite Helen's dismissive remarks about Mary's ambition, suggesting either restraint or passivity.
Explains calmly his reasoning for changing his mind about bringing Mary along, showing reflection and consideration.
Takes charge by directing Steve sharply to round up the horses and not keep the people waiting, demonstrating leadership and decisiveness.
Spurs his hesitant horse into the river and swims toward Mary to rescue her from drowning.
Reaches down to lift Mary onto his horse and manages to get both of them safely to shore.
Shows anxious expression and tenderness, indicating emotional engagement rather than purely strategic or skillful behavior.
Anxiously asks Mary if she is all right after her accident.
Gets nettled at Mary's sharp tone, showing irritation.
Mocks Mary for worrying about her clothes after losing the wagon.
Calls Mary stupid and angrily blames her for the wagon loss.

Commands others to act promptly and takes initiative by mounting his horse and plunging into the stream without delay.

Loads the saddle and prepares Steve's horse despite Steve's hurt and anger.
After Steve leaves, smiles softly watching him ride off.
Hurries to Steve when he returns to the meadow and questions him.

Successfully bandages Steve's shoulder and tends to his injury with care and practical skill.

Thanks Mary for taking over holding the lamp, shows appreciation.

Focuses on Steve during the medical treatment, visibly shaken and attentive.

Observes Steve riding beside Mary and reins in his horse, implying attentiveness and perhaps protective or considerate behavior toward his group.
